abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Health and Family
            Planning Project for Sri Lanka was unsatisfactory. The
            project achieved some of its objectives, its impact on
            institutional development was partially successful,
            sustainability is likely, and the performance of both the
            Bank and Borrower was less than satisfactory. Several
            lessons can be learned from this project. First, in project
            development, failure by IDA to understand fully and take
            adequate account of the priorities of the implementing
            ministry led to the lack of "ownership" of the
            project on the part of that ministry, which seriously
            compromised implementation. Second, in project development,
            failure by IDA to ensure that senior managers understood and
            supported project strategies for assistance to specific
            programs resulted in the consequent failure to utilize
            assistance for those programs. Third, project ownership and
            implementation difficulties were further exacerbated by the
            complexity of the project. Fourth, lack of effective project
            management in the early stages of the project was a key
            factor in implementation difficulties. Fifth, better
            familiarization of project staff with IDA procurement
            guidelines and procedures would have helped to avoid delays
            in the procurement of equipment, furniture, and supplies.
            Finally, the frank mid-term assessment of project status
            carried out by the implementing ministry played a key role
            in the mid-term revision of the project.
